sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for PFV inflection: 3pl.m/c in sound verbs.

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

cit.quote: fa čānaw yiskənūn-u liʔannu yirḥalūn min ṃakān li-ʔāxar
They used to live in them because they go from one place to another

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Only a few occurrences found in a 61-year old male.

cit.quote: The children saw a beggar behind our house

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Only some speakers, generally over 70 years have been documented to use this ending. Generally these speakers tend to show variation between -um and -u, being the latter the only suffix among the middle-age and young generations
CaCaC verbs follow the CaCaCu pattern when in PFV 3.pl.c and CiCiC verbs follow CiCCu in PFV 3.pl.c
-au documented for pausal forms

Pickett (2005:240-241) notes: "Those tribes that exhibit -am as the suffix, the ʔAbū ʕīd, ʔAbū Ǧabal and the Ḥarūk, may also occasionally exhibit a final diphthong -aw, usually (but not exclusively) in pausal positions".

Pickett (2005:240-241) notes: "Those tribes that exhibit -am as the suffix, the ʔAbū ʕīd, ʔAbū Ǧabal and the Ḥarūk, may also occasionally exhibit a final diphthong -aw, usually (but not exclusively) in pausal positions".

Pickett (2005:240-241) notes: "Those tribes that exhibit -am as the suffix, the ʔAbū ʕīd, ʔAbū Ǧabal and the Ḥarūk, may also occasionally exhibit a final diphthong -aw, usually (but not exclusively) in pausal positions".

Pickett (2005:240-241) notes: "Those tribes that exhibit -am as the suffix, the ʔAbū ʕīd, ʔAbū Ǧabal and the Ḥarūk, may also occasionally exhibit a final diphthong -aw, usually (but not exclusively) in pausal positions".

Pickett (2005:240-241) notes: "Those tribes that exhibit -am as the suffix, the ʔAbū ʕīd, ʔAbū Ǧabal and the Ḥarūk, may also occasionally exhibit a final diphthong -aw, usually (but not exclusively) in pausal positions".

Pickett (2005:240-241) notes: "Those tribes that exhibit -am as the suffix, the ʔAbū ʕīd, ʔAbū Ǧabal and the Ḥarūk, may also occasionally exhibit a final diphthong -aw, usually (but not exclusively) in pausal positions".
Younes (2013:46) specifies that -aw occurrs in emphatic environments, and -u in non emphatic ones.
Younes (2013:46) specifies that -aw occurrs in emphatic environments, and -u in non emphatic ones.
As for this ending Palva 1980:124 reports the suffix -ow which was not attested in the new data collected and published by Torzullo 2022
the author only provides the prefixes and suffixes, no declinations
mostly predominant after gutturals
deducted from ex.
in Ḥāyl ktubaw "they wrote"
often -aw becomes -om (ktibow, širbow, etc.)
Deduced from examples
Deduced from examples.
When no suffix is attached, the first syllable of this strong verb is stressed
Panetta (1943) attests this suffix alongside -ow
The 3.c.pl. endings -aw, -o, -u are freely variant in non-stressed positions (Johnstone 1967:70)
Deduced from examples
The suffix -um is much more frequent than the usual suffix -u, especially in pause.
The suffix -um is rarer than -uw.
after vowel: -w
after vowel: -w
after vowel: -w
with a suffix -u becomes -ō-, e.g.: ma-šarbō-š 'they didn't drink'
